sub_topic: Probability of a certain demographic group being affected by a disease
message_1: What is the probability that out of a randomly selected group of 500 individuals, 60 will be affected by a specific disease if the overall incidence rate of the disease in the population is 6%?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula, which is:

P(x) = (nCx) * (p^x) * (1-p)^(n-x)

where:
- P(x) is the probability of having x successes (in this case, 60 individuals affected by the disease) in n trials (in this case, 500 individuals)
- nCx is the number of combinations of n items taken x at a time (also written as C(n, x) or "n choose x")
- p is the probability of success (in this case, the incidence rate of the disease, 6% or 0.06)
- x is the number of successes (in this case, 60 individuals)
- n is the number of trials (in this case, 500 individuals)

First, we need to calculate nCx, which is:

nCx = n! / (x!(n-x)!)

where ! denotes the factorial of a number.

In this case, n = 500 and x = 60, so:

nCx = 500! / (60!(500-60)!)

Now, we can plug these values into the binomial probability formula:

P(60) = (nCx) * (p^x) * (1-p)^(n-x)
P(60) = (500! / (60!(500-60)!)) * (0.06^60) * (1-0.06)^(500-60)

Calculating this expression, we get:

So, the probability that out of a randomly selected group of 500 individuals, 60 will be affected by the specific disease is approximately 3.94%.
